722387f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Avenue - 105th Street
722387f-a.text:
Park Avenue (called Fourth Avenue until about 1890) north from about 105th Street, showing two track railroad on wooden trestle. The little wooded hill in right background is the future Mt. Morris Park. The deepest part of the old Harlem Creek bed is between 106th and 107th Streets. For some reason Drips' Plan of New York for 1867 and for 1868 utterly fails to show the big building in the center of the picture, which should be at about 110th Street and Fifth Avenue, nor any of the buildings just west of Fourth Avenue around 110th Street except the five small houses neanest the camera, on the S.W. corner of 110th Street. The steeple on the horizon to the right is probably the Mt. Morris Baptist Church at Fifth Avenue
near 126th Street; this is, howeven, only a guess.
This photograph was used as an illustration in the first of Henny Collins Brown's Valentine's Manuwle, 1916-17, opposite page 91.
1860.
New York Edison Company Collection.
N7c-ww S 22S
ARg R 0G9

722388f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Avenue - 105th Street
722388f-a.text:
Park Avenue, west side, north from and including 1422 Park Avenue, between 105th and 10oth Streets. The sign reads "Fish Market" twice, once in English and once in Hebrew characters.
July 6, 1934.
L. Sperr.

714976f-a.title: Manhattan: 105th Street (East) - Park Avenue
714976f-a.text:
East 105th Street, south side, east from, but not includinp Park, to and including Madison Aves. In the imnediate foreground, is a synagogue BDeth Tamidrash Hagodol of Harlem (No. 110), with the Hebrew Pomo for the Aged (Nos. 114-118) adjoining. P.S. No. 72 Annex is shown adjoining the S.N. corhner of Lexington Ave.
AuCust 31, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
